Core Utilities#

Utility functions.

jrystal._src.utils.absolute_square(array: Complex[Array, '...']) → Float[Array, '...']#

Compute the element-wise absolute square of a complex array.

Parameters:

array (Array) – Input complex array.

Returns:

An array containing the absolute square of each element.

Return type:

Array

jrystal._src.utils.expand_coefficient(coeff_compact: Complex[Array, 'spin kpt band gpt'], mask: Bool[Array, 'x y z']) → Complex[Array, 'spin kpt band x y z']#

Expand coefficients based on the provided mask. The sum of the mask should equal the last dimension of coeff_dense.

Example:

>>> shape = (5, 6, 7)
>>> mask = np.random.randn(*shape) > 0
>>> ng = jnp.sum(mask)
>>> cg = jnp.ones([2, 3, ng])

>>> print(_coeff_expand(cg, mask).shape)
>>> (2, 3, 5, 6, 7)
Parameters:

  • coeff_dense (Complex[Array, “*batch ng”]) – Dense coefficient array.

  • mask (Bool[Array, ‘*ndim’]) – Boolean mask array.

Returns:

Expanded coefficients with shape (*batch, *ndim).

Return type:

Complex[Array, “*batch ng”]

jrystal._src.utils.fft_factor(n: int)#

Get fftw factor n = 2^a * 3^b * 5^c *7 ^d * 11^e * 13^f and e/f = 0/1 prime_factor_list = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13] smaller than 2049.

jrystal._src.utils.safe_real(array: Array, tol: float = 1e-08) → Array#

Convert a complex array to a real array if its imaginary part is effectively zero.

Parameters:

  • array (Array) – Input array, can be real or complex.

  • tol (float) – Tolerance for the imaginary part to be considered zero.

Returns:

A real array if the imaginary part is effectively zero.

Return type:

Array

Raises:

ValueError – If the array has a non-zero imaginary part.

jrystal._src.utils.squeeze_coefficient(coeff: Complex[Array, 'spin kpts band x y z'], mask: Bool[Array, 'spin kpts band x y z']) → Complex[Array, 'spin kpts num_g band']#

Reshape the parameter to a compact shape with the mask, and the swap the last two axes such that the for each spin and kpt, the coefficients are a tall matrix where number of rows are greater than the number of columns.

Parameters:

  • coeff (Complex[Array, "spin kpts band x y z"]) – The coefficient array.

  • mask (Bool[Array, "spin kpts band x y z"]) – The mask array.

Returns:

The squeezed coefficient array.

Return type:

Complex[Array, “spin kpts num_g band”]

jrystal._src.utils.vmapstack(times: int, args: List[Dict] = None) → Callable#

Apply JAX’s vmap function multiple times over a function.

Example

If f maps (3) -> (2), then vmapstack(f) maps (*batches, 3) -> (*batches, 2).

Parameters:

  • times (int) – Number of times to apply vmap. Must match the dimension of the

  • batches.

  • args (List[Dict], optional) – Arguments for each vmap application. Defaults

  • None. (to)

Returns:

A function that maps from (*batches, _) to (*batches, _).

Return type:

Callable

Raises:

ValueError – If the length of args does not match the number of times.

jrystal._src.utils.volume(cell_vectors: Float[Array, '3 3']) → Float#

Calculate the volume of a 3D grid given its shape and spacing.

Parameters:

cell_vectors (CellVector) – The cell vectors of the crystal.

Returns:

The volume of the cell_vectors.

Return type:

float

jrystal._src.utils.wave_to_density(wave_grid: Complex[Array, '... n1 n2 n3'], occupation: Float[Array, 'spin kpts band'] | Int[Array, 'spin kpts band'] | None = None, axis: int | Tuple | List | None = None) → Float[Array, '... n1 n2 n3']#

Compute the density grid from the wave_grid and occupation mask, returning real space density values at grid points.

Parameters:

  • wave_grid (ScalarGrid[Complex, 3]) – Wave function values at grid points.

  • occupation (OccupationArray, optional) – Occupation mask. If provided, the

  • provided (density will be reduced according to the occupation mask. If not)

:param : :param the output density will have the same shape as wave_grid. Defaults to: :param None.: :param axis: Axis or axes along which a :type axis: int | Tuple | List | None, optional :param contraction with the occupation mask is performed. If not provided: :param the: :param function will reduce over all the spin: :param kpoint: :param and bands axes.:

Returns:

the density evaluated at grid in real space.

Return type:

ScalarGrid[Float, 3]

jrystal._src.utils.wave_to_density_reciprocal(wave_grid: Complex[Array, '... n1 n2 n3'], occupation: Float[Array, 'spin kpts band'] | Int[Array, 'spin kpts band'] = None, axis: int | Tuple | List | None = None) → Float[Array, '... n1 n2 n3']#

Compute the density grid from the wave_grid and occupation mask, returning reciprocal space density values at grid points.

Parameters:

  • wave_grid (ScalarGrid[Complex, 3]) – Wave function values at grid points.

  • occupation (OccupationArray, optional) – Occupation mask. If provided, the

  • provided (density will be reduced according to the occupation mask. If not)

:param : :param the output density will have the same shape as wave_grid. Defaults to: :param None.: :param axis: Axis or axes along which a :type axis: int | Tuple | List | None, optional :param contraction with the occupation mask is performed. If not provided: :param the: :param function will reduce over all the spin: :param kpoint: :param and bands axes.:

Returns:

the density evaluated at grid in reciprocal space.

Return type:

ScalarGrid[Float, 3]
